header.title: Data Types

section.title: Terms
section.p: Erlang provides a number of data types which are listed in this chapter. A piece of data of any data type is called a term.

section.title: Number
section.p: There are two types of numeric literals, integers and floats. Besides the conventional notation, there are two Erlang-specific notations:

list.item:
$char
ASCII value of the character char.

base#value
Integer with the base base, which must be an integer in the range 2..36.
In Erlang 5.2/OTP R9B and earlier versions, the allowed range is 2..16.

section.p: An atom is a literal, a constant with name. An atom should be enclosed in single quotes (') if it does not begin with a lower-case letter or if it contains other characters than alphanumeric characters, underscore (_), or @.

section.title: Bit Strings and Binaries
section.p: A bit string is used to store an area of untyped memory.
Bit Strings are expressed using the bit syntax.
Bit Strings which consists of a number of bits which is evenly divisible by eight are called Binaries
Examples:
More examples can be found in Programming Examples.

section.title: Reference
section.p: A reference is a term which is unique in an Erlang runtime system, created by calling make_ref/0.

section.title: Fun
section.p: A fun is a functional object. Funs make it possible to create an anonymous function and pass the function itself -- not its name -- as argument to other functions.
Example:
Read more about funs in Fun Expressions. More examples can be found in Programming Examples.

section.title: Port Identifier
section.p: A port identifier identifies an Erlang port. open_port/2, which is used to create ports, will return a value of this type.
Read more about ports in Ports and Port Drivers.

section.title: Pid
section.p: A process identifier, pid, identifies a process. spawn/1,2,3,4, spawn_link/1,2,3,4 and spawn_opt/4, which are used to create processes, return values of this type. Example:
The BIF self() returns the pid of the calling process. Example:
section.pre:
-module(m). -export([loop/0]).
loop() -> receive who_are_you -> io:format("I am ~p~n", [self()]), loop() end.
1> P = spawn(m, loop, []). <0.58.0> 2> P ! who_are_you. I am <0.58.0> who_are_you
section.p: Read more about processes in Processes.

section.title: Tuple
section.p: Compound data type with a fixed number of terms:
Each term Term in the tuple is called an element. The number of elements is said to be the size of the tuple.
There exists a number of BIFs to manipulate tuples.
Examples:
section.pre: 1> P = {adam,24,{july,29}}. {adam,24,{july,29}} 2> element(1,P). adam 3> element(3,P). {july,29} 4> P2 = setelement(2,P,25). {adam,25,{july,29}} 5> tuple_size(P). 3 6> tuple_size({}). 0

section.title: Map
section.p: Compound data type with a variable number of key-value associations:
Each key-value association in the map is called an association pair. The key and value parts of the pair are called elements. The number of association pairs is said to be the size of the map.
There exists a number of BIFs to manipulate maps.
Examples:
section.pre: 1> M1 = #{name=>adam,age=>24,date=>{july,29}}. #{age => 24,date => {july,29},name => adam} 2> maps:get(name,M1). adam 3> maps:get(date,M1). {july,29} 4> M2 = maps:update(age,25,M1). #{age => 25,date => {july,29},name => adam} 5> map_size(M). 3 6> map_size(#{}). 0
section.p: A collection of maps processing functions can be found in the STDLIB module maps.
Read more about Maps.

note.p: Maps are considered experimental during OTP 17.

section.title: List
section.p: Compound data type with a variable number of terms.
Each term Term in the list is called an element. The number of elements is said to be the length of the list.

Formally, a list is either the empty list [] or consists of a head (first element) and a tail (remainder of the list) which is also a list. The latter can be expressed as [H|T]. The notation [Term1,...,TermN] above is actually shorthand for the list [Term1|[...|[TermN|[]]]].

Example:
[] is a list, thus
[c|[]] is a list, thus
[b|[c|[]]] is a list, thus
[a|[b|[c|[]]]] is a list, or in short [a,b,c].
A list where the tail is a list is sometimes called a proper list. It is allowed to have a list where the tail is not a list, for example [a|b]. However, this type of list is of little practical use.
Examples:
A collection of list processing functions can be found in the STDLIB module lists.

section.title: String
section.p: Strings are enclosed in double quotes ("), but is not a data type in Erlang. Instead a string "hello" is shorthand for the list [$h,$e,$l,$l,$o], that is [104,101,108,108,111].

section.title: Record
section.p: A record is a data structure for storing a fixed number of elements. It has named fields and is similar to a struct in C. However, record is not a true data type. Instead record expressions are translated to tuple expressions during compilation. Therefore, record expressions are not understood by the shell unless special actions are taken. See shell(3) for details.
Examples:
Read more about records in Records. More examples can be found in Programming Examples.

section.p: There is no Boolean data type in Erlang. Instead the atoms true and false are used to denote Boolean values.
